3264231642.resolved_title: The Once-Classified Tale of Juanita Moody
3264231642.excerpt: On the morning of Sunday, October 14, 1962, Juanita Moody exited the headquarters of the National Security Agency, at Fort Meade, Maryland, and walked the short distance to her car, parked in one of the front-row spaces reserved for top leadership.

1.caption:
Moody, seen in 1943, was an undergraduate at Western Carolina Teacher's College when she volunteered for  the Army and became a wunderkind code breaker at the Signal Intelligence Service, forerunner of the NSA.
    
    
      Susan Seubert

2.caption:
The National Security Agency was established on October 24, 1952, in a secret memo signed by President Harry Truman. Moody was there from Day 1.
    
    
      NSA

3.caption:
Moody was instrumental in the NSA’s use of new technology
to process critical intelligence. Below, IBM machines at the agency.
    
    
      NSA

4.credit: Raul Corrales, The Canadian Press / AP Images
4.caption:
Fidel Castro observes the battle at the Bay of Pigs in April 1961 as the invasion was underway. The attack led Castro to eventually allow Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.
    
    
      Raul Corrales, The Canadian Press / AP Images

5.caption:
A 1961 NSA memo detailing intercepted intelligence that Spanish-speaking pilots were undergoing flight training in Soviet-aligned Czechoslovakia.
    
    
      NSA

6.caption:
Left, Richard Goodwin, an adviser to the president
at the State Department, joined Lansdale in the fateful closed door meeting with Moody at Fort Meade. Right, Col. Edward Lansdale, an assistant secretary of defense,
requested that Moody compile her intercepted Cuban intelligence into a classified report in fall 1961.
    
    
      Bettmann / Getty Images; AP / Shutterstock

7.caption:
Louis Tordella, deputy director of the NSA, was conflicted about circulating Moody’s report about Cuba’s military buildup; in early 1962, he relented.
    
    
      NSA

8.caption:
The coffin of U.S. Air Force Maj. Rudolph Anderson Jr., a
U-2 pilot, is loaded onto a Swiss airplane in Havana. He was shot down during a reconnaissance flight on October 27, 1962.
    
    
      Prensa / Latina via AP Images

2758973179.given_title: A Beginner’s Guide To Flight Tracking
2758973179.resolved_title: A Beginner's Guide To Flight Tracking
2758973179.excerpt: Flight tracking is an accessible and useful tool for open source investigators. Being able to track the movements of aircraft belonging to powerful individuals and armed forces can add important details to stories, or even uncover entire new narratives.

1.caption: The FlightRadar24 interface showing flights over Ecuador

2.caption: Hovering your cursor over an aircraft on Radar Box’s default interface will show you important information about the flight, including the aircraft type and destination/arrival cities. In this image, we can see that the aircraft is Avianca’s AV47

3.caption: Flight Aware’s delays page sorts information by airlines as well as origin and destination airport

4.caption: To filter the map to display only military aircraft, click the “Menu” button on the top left of the live traffic map. Then, click the “Filters” tab. Select “Military” from the drop-down menu, and then click “Enable Filters”. Seen here, a United States Air Force Lockheed C-130H Hercules over the eastern Mediterranean

5.caption: ADS-B Exchange also tracks some military aircraft. Seen here, a US Army UH-72A Lakota helicopter flying near the Mexico border just south of El Paso, Texas

6.caption: Aeromexico’s flight AM646 en route to Los Angeles. Note the aircraft’s registration: XA-ADH

7.caption: An example of an entry for Trump Force One

9.caption: Note that the website tells us that it has record

10.caption: Searching for the registration on Flight Radar 24 shows us pictures of YV3016, which company operates the aircraft, and that it is an Embraer Lineage 1000, as well as other information

11.caption: According to Flight Radar 24, YV3016 flew to Moscow on May 5, and then to Istanbul on May 7. However, Conviasa does not fly those routes

3334779478.given_title: Unsure When a Video or Photo was Taken? How to Tell by Measuring the Length
3334779478.resolved_title: Unsure When a Video or Photo was Taken? How to Tell by Measuring the Length of Shadows
3334779478.excerpt: Establishing the time within a video or image can be a difficult and frustrating task for open source researchers. If you’re lucky, you’ll get a brief glance at a wall-clock or wristwatch — but in most cases you won’t. Measuring shadows, however, can help provide a solution.

1.caption: The Al Aqsa compound in Jerusalem. Photo by Nick Waters.

2.caption: The Al Aqsa compound in Jerusalem with shadow measurements added. Photo by Nick Waters.

3.caption: Suncalc.org calculation of shadow length. Click or tap to see full size image.

5.caption: Still image from a video posted by Mohammad al-Hadad with shadow measurements added.

3292592772.excerpt: Reading a good book is a great joy. And recommending a good book is almost as enjoyable. I’ve long been fascinated by books on espionage, and this contributed in no small part to me eventually joining the Dutch intelligence world, and lately, rejoining it in some fashion.

2763315867.given_title: What the U.S. Can Learn From Iranian Warfare
2763315867.resolved_title: What the U.S. Can Learn From Iranian Warfare
2763315867.excerpt: The Iranian approach to proxy warfare offers a surprising lesson. In July 2006 in south Beirut, Qassem Soleimani was facing death.
